ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: You learn to consider your life rather than moving through it blindly. You get to survey many different religious traditions and discuss them with an open-mind among your classmates. The course culminates in a final paper on your vision of a life worth living, in which you really need to push yourself to be critical of the life you have led and the one you hope to lead into the future.
I learned about a lot of new traditions and religions and traced what I thought defined a life worth living.
We discussed how different traditions understand what is important in life through the lens of the course questions.
I learned a bit about how to question and view my own vision of a life worth living.

I feel I got a great exposure to various religious traditions/ways of thinking about life that I would never have encountered otherwise. I also think my skills of self-reflection, especially self-reflection in writing, improved greatly.

This is basically a comparative religion course, but I did not gain any deep understanding of the religions we studied. We were provided with no history of context, only specific passages and ideas. This made the course more personally relevant to everyone, but makes me feel like I didn't learn much.
I thought more deeply about what is important in my life.

I learned about the history of several religions and traditions (Christianity, Judaism, Islam, etc). Beyond this knowledge, I improved my abilities to engage in rigorous analysis of texts and to discuss this analysis with others. I also began viewing my choices and those of others with a more analytical eye. This course has made me more aware of discrepancies between what I claim matters to me and what I prioritize in my actions!
This was an amazing course where you learn a lot about yourself and your classmates.
An overview of all major religious traditions and their vision of a life worth living. How to concretely discuss visions of purpose and meaning.
Thinking skills, reflection skills, questioning
Introduction to various world views
I learned so much about different religions and beliefs. I really enjoyed it and I will never forget the conversations in class.

You will learn about the various frameworks proposed by major religions for answering the course questions (What is a life worth living? What is a human? What role does suffering play in our lives? etc.).

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Everyone in the class was so engaged with the material and incredibly present. The readings were generally well selected but could be shortened. You could tell everyone wanted to be there.

Strengths--really thought-provoking and the best part of the course was thinking through your own vision of a life worth living at the end. Weaknesses- a lot of reading and wish that I had a bit more of a foundational knowledge on the religions/traditions we learned about. A lecture on the foundation of religion before diving into complicated texts would be nice.

It's hard to judge the course by my experience because my section was not the optimal iteration of this course -- there were too many students and we were not able to go on the retreat which is said to be an important part of the course. It often felt like a shoddily-constructed introduction to world religions class, which is not what it was intended to be. It was fun to analyze my own life, and I find myself thinking about what I wrote in the three papers for the course.
I think the readings could be much be made simpler and more accessible. Some were pretty tough to read and make sense of.
At times it felt a little disorganized. I think the content is interesting but it was not executed to the level I would have liked.

I believe one of the greatest strengths of this course is the readings- even independent of the class discussions these proved very valuable and interesting. I felt that the discussions were at times limiting. We may have been able to get more value out of these readings if conversations were able to focus on what most drew our attention.  The plenary sessions were fantastic, and some were definitely my favorite class meetings.
The conversations were really good and I thought the readings were fairly interesting. I think our class was a little large which made participating in conversations a little difficult.
Strengths are Professor Collins and the entire seminar of seniors. It's organized and well thought-out, purposeful and deliberate. The plenaries are also interesting.
Very discussion-based, encouraged creative thought

Strengths - eye opening, exposure to a lot of different world perspectives
Weaknesses - would appreciate more depth for each world view

The course structure was very repetitive (readings followed by discussion of those readings every class), which lowered the overall engagement of the class as the time went on. I found that many students were not doing the readings, leading to discussions that were tangential to the readings at best.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: An amazing course for anyone at any stage of life! Too often, me move through life without thinking about the choices we are making and how they align with our values. This course forces you to pause and consider your life, your community, and the things that matter most to you.
Yes! Really great for seniors about to graduate. Frankly, it would be best if this class was limited to seniors/juniors.
Sure. If you are looking for an interesting, low workload course Id take this one. However, although the papers were short they were quite hard to write.

If you are interested in exploring the meaning of life from various perspectives, and spending more dedicated time thinking about your own (especially before graduating Yale), I would absolutely recommend!
The best part of this class are the personal essays, so only take it if you are prepared to invest in them.

I would maybe recommend this course to another student but not with Professor Collins. I had initially thought because he had taught the course many times before he would be a better professor than most of the other professors, but I think he lacked the engagement that some of the other professors had (only really from the plenary lectures).

If you are interested in learning more about well known traditions and the tensions that exist within and between them, I highly recommend this course. If you are interested in better understanding your own priorities and goals, it is also valuable. I noticed a genuine change in how I view my life and my actions and how I discuss those choices with others.
YES
Yes! Every Yale student should take this course.
Yes, absolutely!
I would recommend this course to another student because it challenges what you believe
Yes!! I would recommend this class to every single person whos interested in thinking about the meaning of their lives.
I would recommend this course. It forces you to think introspectively about what you value in your life from analyzing the many texts of world religions.
